BE11:16am

The things to note are the 6% discount to Monday's price and the fairly big sale. None of which sound like great news for the stock's immediate prospects.

BE11:16am

Liberum incoming:

11:16 am
BE11:16am

This sale is not wholly a surprise considering his departure from the board and a senior management role at Super Dry earlier this year but it also potentially raises the question of what the ex-CEO thinks about the value of the current share price. Liberum has a TP of 1400p, some 2.6% ahead of the current share price with the shares having risen 17.4% the past month (on no news flow). At our TP the shares trade on 15x PE and 7.5x EV/EBITDA which we think is fair for now until we see a return to margin expansion alongside double digit sales growth.

To turn more positive on a longer term view, we need greater clarity on: (i) earnings momentum – this has slowed from the historic strong double-digit growth rates; (ii) brand vision, focus and values - the group is no longer founder-led, following the exit of Julian Dunkerton, which we feel increases the risk, and (iii) positive operational gearing - operating profit margins have declined every year since 2014 when they were 14.4% and forecast to trough at 11.3% in the year to April 2019E. We look to see a signal that the group’s move towards a more capital light model will see better conversion of sales growth into margin accretion.

madrugada Any comments on Just Group?
BE11:17am

They go back to "hold" on valuation grounds.

MassimoJ Thoughts on Fulham Shore? Looks pretty respectable to me given what's happening to their competitors

turns in the past month (from 10.5x to 12.6x on 12-month forward
consensus EPS). The stock offers 8% revenue and 11% EBIT 3-yr CAGR.
We believe risk/reward is fairly balanced with healthy albeit decelerating
revenue momentum, and improving FCF profile (on lower capex) offset
by low likelihood of earnings upgrades and potential deleverage risk from
challenging retail trading conditions.

Just Group PLC (JUST:LSE): Last: 114.70, down 9.7 (-7.80%), High: 127.10, Low: 114.00, Volume: 4.46m
BE11:25am

Impact wise ..... hard to say.

11:25 am
BE11:25am

Here's Barclays.

BE11:25am

Just has highlighted the PRA’s consultation on equity release mortgages (CP13/18) could impact its capital position if implemented as outlined in the paper. We calculate that the proposals (assuming a 1% deferment rate and no benefit from 16 year Transitional Relief) could reduce Just’s Sol 2 ratio to 121% (from 154%). This level of capital is sufficient for the PRA, but unlikely to be sufficient for the public markets. Just has various options in this hypothetical case to improve capital, including increased use of reinsurance, increased debt leverage, slower new business sales or an equity raise, although all of which come with an earnings impact. In our view, Just is already trading at a run-off valuation (68% of year end tangible book value estimate of 176p), and hence much of the risk already priced in to the stock.

BE11:26am

And RBC.

11:26 am
BE11:26am

Just Group says in today’s statement that the “consultation paper does contain proposals, which if implemented would result in a reduction in Just’s regulatory capital position”. It has not quantified “a reduction” although we have. Using the sensitivities provided by Just Group we have calculated that if the PRA requires insurers to use a 1%pa negative house price inflation (HPI) assumption we expect the Solvency II ratio to move from 154% to 151% (spread over 3 years). If the PRA requires 2% negative HPI then the ratio would move to 144%. We forecast the PRA to require a 1% negative HPI as we expect both the industry (Association of British Insurers) and the Equity release council to push back strongly.

BE11:27am

Just skim reading the rest of that RBC note ......

BE11:28am

Just Group will also benefit from the life expectancy slowdown.

11:28 am
BE11:28am

.... uh?

BE11:29am

While it is not normal for insurers to release mortality reserves mid-year some may do this. If a CFO was in any doubt one look at the number of deaths in the first half of 2018 would confirm that 2018 is proving to be the worst year for deaths this millennium. This is likely to make insurers release reserves sooner than later.

BE11:29am

I did not know this!

11:29 am
BE11:29am

2018 is a banner year for death. Running close to 2015.

1st Lt. Fletcher Christian Anyone interested in any Drax info?
BE11:30am

Deaths in the first half of 2018 were 5.2% ahead of 2017 and 2.1% ahead of 2015.

BE11:30am

The number of deaths in Q2 (discrete) was 129,086, 2.9% higher than 2017. A growing and aging population means one would expect deaths to increase by 2.0%pa. Therefore, adjusting for population effects, relative to last year, mortality rates have deteriorated by 0.9%. This is in marked contrast to the reserving assumption of UK insurers who assume mortality improves by 1.5-2.0%.

11:30 am
BE11:30am

Why, tho? It wasn't a bad flu season.

BE11:31am

And it's a trend. A British trend.

BE11:31am

Between 2011 and 2016 the life expectancy of British men improved by 5 months, while there was no improvement for British women. Life expectancy improvement was greater in the large economies of Germany, Spain and Italy.

11:31 am
BE11:31am

Malta witnessed the greatest improvement in male life expectancy, while Luxembourg was best in class for women. Only Iceland witnessed slower life expectancy improvement than the UK.

BE11:31am

BE11:41am

DRX’s 2017 interim results came in lower than our expectations at £102m EBITDA versus our estimate of £119m, with the difference largely attributable to the Generation segment (£88m vs. JPMe £108m) due to
outages in the period having a more significant impact than we had initially forecast. Alleviating matters is an improvement in 2H operating profit expectations due to a better than expected improvement in the hedge book, with 2018 hedges prices edging higher from c.£43.8/MWh to c.£45.1/MWh. As a result we arrive back at square one, with expectations for 2018 still on track (outlook commentary points to 2018 ‘expectations unchanged’) implying no consensus EPS downgrades pending. On the dividend front, guidance provided today for 2018 implies growth of 12.6% yoy which is a significant improvement against our estimate of 8.6%. In addition gearing (ND/EBITDA) once again points to funding headroom emerging at the end of the year and while further accretive investment in pellet production has been announced, capex will remain within the existing £100-110m guidance band.

From this we conclude that the beneficial impact of higher commodity prices in the remaining months of the year in Generation will offset the negative impact of the weaker 1H. If not for the one-off impact of the Generation outages, we would have been looking at a healthy c.£20m upgrade to ~£270m. As it is, we remain comfortable with our current c.£250m estimate which is broadly in line with BB consensus.

Importantly, we find it unlikely TSLA would be asking for concessions from a position of weakness; we think the report could be an indication production is ramping.

BE11:53am

Throughout our coverage of TSLA, we have noted the company can be a major source of growth for suppliers, but also a challenging customer. As volumes ramp significantly (2018E consensus delivery estimates is ~235k vehicles, up from ~103k in 2017), we think TSLA will have the ability to renegotiate supply agreements and improve profitability.

CS1 @BE: is it true, 30 degrees C in the underground?
BE11:54am

Citi's not so keen.

11:54 am
BE11:54am

Although “price-down” requests by automakers to suppliers are fairly common (as are commercial settlements of prior work/projects), what stuck out to us as a negative is that Tesla’s memo reportedly described the request as essential to the company’s continued operation. To us, such language can be interpreted to suggest that Tesla requires these supplier refunds to shore up its balance sheet liquidity as opposed to offsetting cost headwinds or boosting margins (the latter two being more common). Given the state of Tesla’s balance sheet, any signs of unusual actions to shore up cash are likely to be viewed negatively by investors, particularly given how important supplier credit terms are to an automaker’s balance sheet. As such, we think the initial pre-market move in the shares is understandable, though we note there are still a number of outstanding questions as to the actual scope of this reported memo.

BE12:02pm

Here's Morgan Stanley.

12:02 pm
BE12:02pm

In the US market, revenue grew by 23% in constant currency terms which is solid given that H1 was a transitional period from working with an agent to having established Fever-Tree wholly owned operations. Looking ahead we remain confident about the US opportunity and are reassured by the announcement today of an exclusive distribution partnership with Southern Wine and Spirits
across 29 states (the largest spirits wholesaler in the US).
In Europe, revenue grew by 15% on constant currency basis lapping a tough comp (+53%).
Based on the strong H1 results, Fever-Tree now expects the outcome for the year to be “comfortably ahead of its expectations”. We expect mid to high single digit upgrades based on today’s statement compared to consensus and new full year expectations. Given the recent strength of the stock, Fever-Tree is currently trading on 65x CY19 PE. This statement / upgrade should add to confidence in the longer term equity thesis.

Soundbuy ............can't grow into that valuation till every man, woman and child's sticking tonic on their cornflakes...
BornCynic @luzh - wrong site for tips, BE has too much sense than to hand out tips (and the FT lawyers have probably sent him on a training course).
BE12:03pm

And Jefferies.

BE12:03pm

Key positives: 1) UK - still growing strongly. Against tough comps that were boosted by
some sell-in ahead of July 2017 off-trade promotions, UK growth was strong +73% (JEFe
+30%). We believe that growth is equally split across on and off-trade, with boost from
both distribution and rate of sale growth. 2) US. Co is "encouraged" with the move to own
sales force in the US. Agreement signed with SWGS, largest N.American wine and spirits
distribution company, to be exclusive distributor in on-trade across 29 states effective 1
Aug. We anticipate a smooth transition and see opportunities for co-promotions with spirits
companies such as DGE, Bacardi and Pernod.
Key negatives: 1) Europe: relatively subdued growth 17% vs tough comps, with 1H17
boosted by a pre-summer sell-in. New distribution agreement with Grupo Damm to provide
more distribution strength in Spain. Note that comps ease into 2H (+28% vs 1H +64%).
